questions.text: A 22-year-old woman develops a red rash over her cheeks, and pain and swelling in both knees as well as several small joints in her hands. Medical evaluation reveals oral ulceration and 3+ proteinuria. Which of the following is the most sensitive test for the diagnosis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

ANAs

ANAs are present in 98% of patients with SLE. Repeatedly negative tests make the diagnosis of SLE very unlikely. Unfortunately, the test is not specific and may be positive in normal people (especially in older individuals), or secondary to infections, drugs, or other autoimmune disorders.

questions.text: A previously healthy 19-year-old female university student develops myalgia, headache, fever, and malaise. Blood tests reveal lymphocytosis, with 20% of the lymphocytes being atypical. She remains tired and unwell for 6 weeks, but repeated tests for heterophil antibody are negative. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

CMV infection

Heterophil antibody-negative mononucleosis syndrome is the most common manifestation of CMV infection in immunocompetent adults and is more common than the similar syndrome caused by toxoplasmosis.

questions.text: What is the possible cause of irreversible dementia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Lewy body


Dementia is chronic, global, usually irreversible deterioration of cognition. Dementia with Lewy bodies is the 3rd most common dementia. Age of onset is typically > 60.

questions.text: A 35 year old male patient with schizophrenia is being treated with clozapine. The patient has to undergo regular blood monitoring because of which side effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Agranulocytosis

Clozapine is an atypical antipsychotic medication commonly used in the treatment of schizophrenia. While it can be an effective treatment, it is associated with certain side effects that require close monitoring. One of the most significant side effects of clozapine is agranulocytosis, which is a severe reduction in the number of white blood cells called granulocytes.

questions.text: Which of the following is not transmitted perinatally?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Mumps

Mumps is primarily transmitted through respiratory droplets from person to person. While it is possible for a pregnant woman to pass the mumps virus to her baby during pregnancy, perinatal transmission of mumps is relatively rare. The main mode of transmission for mumps is person-to- person contact, particularly through respiratory secretions. Therefore, mumps is not typically transmitted perinatally.

questions.text: A young male came with complaints of high grade fever and malaise. His peripheral smear was prepared and is shown below. Diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Plasmodium falciparum

The peripheral smear shows multiple rings inside RBC. In some RBCs only chromatin dots are visible. The clinical diagnosis is falciparum malaria.
In vivax malaria the infected RBC are larger and may show an amoeboid trophozoite with Schuffner dots.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the clinic with a painless, firm, subcutaneous nodule on his left shin, which has been gradually increasing in size over the past few weeks. He denies any recent trauma or insect bites. On further examination, the lesion is indurated, non-tender, and shows central ulceration with a serous discharge. There are no signs of regional lymphadenopathy. The patient has a history of unprotected sexual intercourse with multiple partners. He denies any other symptoms. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Syphilitic gumma
 
Gummata are growths of pink, fleshy tissue that contain syphilis bacteria. They may appear as nodules or ulcers or become masses that are like tumors. Gummata are rare and may be up to 0.5 in. (1 cm) in size.

questions.text: A 64-year woman with Type II diabetes for 10 years now develops increasing fatigue, dyspnea, and pedal edema. On examination, her blood pressure is 165/90 mm Hg, pulse 90/min, JVP is 4 cm, heart sounds are normal, lungs are clear, and there is 3+ pedal edema. Her urinalysis is positive for 3 gm/L of protein and no casts. Which of the following renal diseases is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Glomerulosclerosis with mesangial thickening

The patient is most likely to develop glomerulosclerosis. This can be diffuse or nodular (Kimmelstiel- Wilson nodules). Poor metabolic control is probably a major factor in the progression of diabetic nephropathy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with underlying COPD develops a viral upper respiratory infection and begins taking an over-the counter    decongestant.    Shortly thereafter he experiences palpitations and presents to the emergency room, where the given rhythm strip is obtained, demonstrating:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Atrial flutter

The rhythm strip in the question reveals atrial flutter with 2:1 atrioventricular (AV) block. Atrial flutter is characterized by an atrial rate of 250 - 350/min; the electrocardiogram typically reveals a sawtooth baseline configuration due to the flutter waves. In the strip, every second atrial depolarization is conducted through the AV node, resulting in a ventricular rate of 75/min.

questions.text: A pregnant lady is a known case of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy and is receiving sodium valproate. Which of the following drugs is best suited after valproate for management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Lamotrigine

In-utero valproate exposure continues to show the highest risk of congenital malformations and of adverse cognitive outcomes, including autism, compared to other AEDs. In-utero exposure to lamotrigine, carbamazepine, phenytoin, and levetiracetam has been evaluated in large numbers of offspring, and all of these AEDs have a low risk of major congenital malformations, near 2.5%.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is on immunosuppressive therapy with steroids post kidney transplantation. She presents with 3 day history of fever, headache and confusion. LP reveals 200 PMN cells /cu.mm with elevated CSF protein. India ink preparation slide is shown. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pneumococcal meningitis

Since the patient is on immunosuppressive regimen, the CMI of the patient is depressed. The altered sensorium of patient has necessitated performing a lumbar puncture. The presence of neutrophils indicates a bacterial infection. India ink preparation slide also shows capsulated diploccoci. Hence answer is A.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man presents to the emergency department for difficulty with walking. His symptoms began approximately 1 week ago and has progressively worsened. He has noticed some light-headedness with standing up from a seated position and some numbness in the bilateral lower extremities. Physical examination is notable for 4/5 power and decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick in the bilateral lower extremity and absent patellar and ankle reflexes. A lumbar puncture is performed, which demonstrates a cell count of 1/uL, protein is 135 mg/dL, and glucose is 65 mg/dL. Which of the following is not associated with the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Autonomic dysfunction is not associated

Autonomic dysfunction (AD) in GBS predominantly occurs in the acute phase of the illness but can manifest in the recovery phase too. The characterized feature of GBS is albumin-cytological dissociation, characterized by elevated proteins due to autoimmunity while the cell count remains perfectly normal. Anormal CSF protein level does not rule out GBS, however, as the level may remain normal in 10% of patients. CSF protein may not rise until 1-2 weeks after the onset of weakness.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with a complaint of muscle weakness that worsens with activity but improves after rest. He reports difficulty in chewing, swallowing, and speaking, particularly at the end of the day. On examination, there is bilateral ptosis and weakness of the extraocular muscles. Deep tendon reflexes are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Myasthenia gravis (MG)

The clinical presentation of muscle weakness worsening with activity but improving after rest, along with ocular symptoms such as bilateral ptosis and weakness of the extraocular muscles, is highly suggestive of myasthenia gravis (MG). MG is an autoimmune neuromuscular disorder characterized by muscle weakness and fatigue, particularly affecting the skeletal muscles that control eye movements, facial expressions, chewing, swallowing, and speaking.

Option A, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS), typically presents with progressive muscle weakness and atrophy, without significant improvement after rest. ALS commonly affects both upper and lower motor neurons, leading to widespread muscle weakness.

Option B, multiple sclerosis (MS), is a chronic autoimmune disease that affects the central nervous system. Although MS can cause various neurological symptoms, it typically presents with sensory and motor deficits that are not usually worsened by activity or improved with rest. In addition, MS commonly presents with symptoms such as optic neuritis, sensory disturbances, and problems with coordination.
 
Option D, Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS), is an acute inflammatory condition affecting peripheral nerves and typically presents with ascending motor weakness and sensory abnormalities. Unlike MG, muscle weakness in GBS does not improve with rest.
Therefore, based on the clinical presentation of muscle weakness worsening with activity, improving after rest, and the presence of bilateral ptosis and weakness of the extraocular muscles, the most likely diagnosis in this case is C) Myasthenia gravis (MG).

questions.text: A 30-year old female presents with complaints of gradual Onset weakness of legs for one month with reduction in Visual acuity and urinary incontinence for past few days. Contrast MRI shows periventricular lesions. The most common ophthalmologic symptom of probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Optic neuritis

Impaired vision is frequently present in patients with MS, most commonly unilateral optic neuritis, which is present in approximately in 66% of cases. Optic neuritis usually manifests as acute or subacute unilateral eye pain that increases with eye movements. It can also lead to blurring or graying of vision or blindness in one eye. However, while unilateral optic neuritis is common in MS, simultaneous bilateral optic neuritis (resulting in total blindness) is rare. Approximately 90% of patients with MS regain normal vision over a period of two to six months after an acute episode of optic neuritis.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest manifestation in the patient presenting with shown physical features?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Loss of diurnal variation

Hypercortisolemia together with the loss of the normal circadian rhythm of cortisol secretion, and disturbed feedback of the HPA axis, are the cardinal biochemical features of Cushing's syndrome. Loss of diurnal variation is earliest manifestation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old male presents with headaches, muscle weakness, and high blood pressure. A basic metabolic panel showed a Na+ of 147 and K+ of 3.1. CT of the abdomen demonstrates bilaterally adrenal hyperplasia. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Conn's disease

In Conns syndrome there is operation of salt escape mechanism that leads to absence of pedal edema. The logic is that though aldosterone is sky high in Conn’s and therefore salt and water retention should cause development of edema, the volume expansion leads to dilatation of right side heart causing release of A.N.P (Atrial Natri-Ureteric Peptide). This product will cause of loss of water and will balance the gain made by aldosterone.

questions.text: Transudative pleural effusion is present in all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Meig's syndrome

questions.text: A 63-year-old male from the middle east presented with hematuria. The urine showed RBCs but no RBC casts. BUN level was normal. cystoscopy revealed an irregular growth on the mucus of the bladder. A biopsy from this growth revealed features of squamous cell carcinoma. The etiology of this cogidition is most likely linked to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Parasitic infection

Schistosoma haematobium is a proven carcinogenic agent that causes mainly bladder squamous cell carcinoma. This type of cancer has characteristic epidemiological, clinical and histopathological features with poor prognosis as compared to other urinary bladder cancers not associated with this parasite.

choices.text: Over dosage of spinal aesthetic agent

questions.text: A 70 years old patient benign prostatic hyperplasia underwent transurethral resection of prostate under spinal anaesthesia. One hour later, he developed vomiting and altered sensorium. The most probable cause is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Water intoxication

Transurethral resection (TUR) syndrome is an iatrogenic form of water intoxication, a combination of fluid overload and hyponatremia that is seen in a variety of endoscopic surgical procedures, although classically after transurethral resection of the prostate (TURP).

questions.text: A 60 years old male presented with fever, chills and dysuria. Patient was hospitalized in emergency for 5 days. PSA level was 7.4. Next best step in this patient:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Antibiotics and admit

A 60 years old male presented with fever, chills and dysuria. Patient was hospitalized in emergency for 5 days. PSA level was 7.4. This patient is most probably suffering from acute bacterial prostatitis and treated by antibiotics.

questions.text: While performing a newborn checkup on a baby boy, a pediatrician discovers the external urethral orifice (urethral opening) is located on the ventral (bottom) surface of the penis, as depicted in the given illustration. What is the most likely diagnosis in this newborn?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypospadias

Hypospadias is a congenital defect of the external genitalia, in which the external urethral orifi ce is incompletely developed and located along the ventral (bottom) surface of the penis. This common anomaly of the external genitalia is seen in approximately 1:300 newborn males.

questions.text: A five years old child presents with ballooning of prepuce after micturition. Examination of penis reveals prepucial adhesions. Which of the following the best treatment:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Conservative management

Circumcision for phimosis should be avoided in children requiring general anesthesia; except in cases with recurrent infections. The procedure should be postponed until the child reaches an age when local anesthesia can be used.

questions.text: A young man gets into a fight after taking beer and is kicked by the lower abdomen. There was pelvic fracture. Blood at meatus. Most likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Rupture of membranous urethra

questions.text: When a ‘spontaneous perforation’ of the esophagus occurs as a result of severe barotrauma while a person vomits against a closed glottis, the condition is known as:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Boerhaave’s syndrome

Boerhaave syndrome is also known as spontaneous esophageal rupture or effort rupture of the esophagus. Although vomiting is thought to be the most common cause, other causes include those that can increase intra-esophageal pressure and cause a barogenic esophageal rupture.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents with a substantial unilateral breast enlargement. She had presumed that this was normal, but on examination, a large, firm tumor is palpated by the attending physician. There is early erosion on the skin. A favourable outlook can be anticipated if the lesion is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cystosarcoma phyllodes

Cystosarcoma phyllodes is a tumor that is very slow growing and has a good prognosis if treated by mastectomy. It is characterized by large polygonal cells with abundant cytoplasm and lymphoid infiltration.

choices.text: Serum amylase > 3 times the upper limit of normal
Serum lipase > 3 times the upper limit of normal

questions.text: A 44-year-old man comes to the emergency department with abdominal pain and nausea for the past 24 hours. The pain started a few hours after dinner, and he describes it as constant pain in the upper part of his abdomen that radiates to his back and flanks. The patient also reports nausea, intermittent vomiting, and abdominal distention. Family history is significant for recurrent episodes of pancreatitis in his father and paternal uncle. He reports drinking an average of 2 alcoholic drinks per week. His temperature is 37.7ºC (99.9ºF), pulse is 92/min, respirations are 20/min, peripheral oxygen saturation is 96%, and blood pressure is 149/94 mmHg. He appears distressed and anxious. Abdominal examination shows tenderness and rigidity over the epigastric and periumbilical regions. Bowel sounds are diminished. Bruising of the umbilicus or flanks are seen. Which of the following laboratory results is the most specific in diagnosing this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Serum lipase > 3 times the upper limit of normal

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker presented with progressive jaundice, pruritus and clay coloured stools for 2 months. History of waxing and waning of jaundice was present. A CT scan revealed dilated main pancreatic duct and common bile duct. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Periampullary carcinoma

“The waxing and waning nature of jaundice is due to sloughing of ampullary cancer, resulting in transient resolution of the jaundice.”

questions.text:
A 50 years old male presented with the history of epigastric pain, anorexia, weight loss and pedal edema. On laboratory examination, total protein  
and albumin was low. Endoscopy was performed and the image is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Menetrier’s disease

History of epigastric pain, anorexia, weight loss and pedal edema and low total protein and albumin levels with massive gastric folds in the stomach giving rise to cobblestone or cerebriform appearance, which is characteristically seen in Menetrier’s disease.

questions.text: A 50 years old male presents with obstructive symptoms. Biopsy of stomach reveals gastrointestinal stromal tumor (GIST). Most appropriate market for GIST is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

CD-117

These results indicate that CD117 is a specific marker for GIST among tumors that occur in the GI tract and adjacent regions.

choices.text: Junction between 2nd and 3rd part of duodenum

questions.text: In a burn patient, the doctor is looking for curling ulcer. Which part should be examined?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

1st part of duodenum

Cushing ulcer: Stress gastritis due to intracranial injury/increased ICP
Curling ulcer: After burn injury (> 35%); in the body and fundus; not in antrum and duodenum Cameron ulcers or riding ulcers: Linear gastric erosions in hiatal hernias

choices.text: IV fluids and antibiotics followed by laparotomy

questions.text: A 30-year-old a male patient presented with abdominal pain, fever, nausea, vomiting and respiratory distress. His BP was found to be 80/40 mm Hg and pulse rate of 115/min. The following chest X-ray was recorded in emergency. What is the immediate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

IV fluids and antibiotics followed by laparotomy

Chest X-ray is showing air under the right dome of diaphragm, which is seen in perforation peritonitis. In cases of perforation peritonitis, laparotomy is the treatment of choice after fluid resuscitation of the patient and IV antibiotics.

questions.text: On 7th post operative day, abdominal wound shows pink serosanguinous discharge. It suggests:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Impending wound dehiscence

questions.text: A young patient was brought to the emergency with colicky abdominal pain, bilious vomiting. CT findings are given below. What is the name of this sign?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Target sign

The given sign is target sign, seen in intussusception.

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl with history of prolonged fever and abdominal discomfort is observed to have splenomegaly and leucopenia. In the course of disease she developed acute abdominal event and died. Which of the following is the likely finding on autopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Longitudinal ulcers

Typhoid fever is associated with the development of longitudinal ulcers. This kind of an ulceration is likely to be associated with bleeding, usually in the third week; but less likely to be associated with a stricture formation.

choices.text: Dilated mucosal and submucosal veins in the colon

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with an episode of syncope. He said he felt dizzy during defecation and noticed gross bleeding in the pan. Fecal occult blood test done 3 months ago as a part of routine screening for colon cancer was negative. There is no history of recent weight loss. What is the likely colonoscopic finding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Dilated mucosal and submucosal veins in the colon

Diagnosis in a 65-year-old patient of bleeding per rectum with syncope and negative fecal occult blood test and no history of recent weight loss is Heyde’s syndrome. The colonoscopic finding in Heyde’s syndrome is dilated mucosal and submucosal veins in the colon.

questions.text: Most common complication of ileostomy is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Skin irritation

MC complication of ileostomy: Skin irritation
MC early complication of ileostomy: Ischemic necrosis

questions.text: A patient gives chronic history of diarrhoea and blood in stool presents with multiple fistulae in the perineum and multiple stricture in small intestine. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

In Crohn’s disease

choices.text: 4 mL/kg × % TBSA in first 8 hours followed by 2 mL/kg/ hour × % TBSA

questions.text: A woman was brought to the casualty 8 hours after sustaining burns on the abdomen, both the limbs and back. What will be the best formula to calculate amount of fluid to be replenished?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

4 mL/kg × %TBSA

questions.text: A patient of motor vehicle accident was admitted to the casualty. He does not speak but moans every now and then, eyes are closed but opens to pain, the right limb is not moving but the left limb shows movement to pain. Both the legs are in extended posture. What will be the GCS score?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

9

questions.text: A patient presented with gradually progressive painless mass since 10 years. It is firm to nodular & variable in consistency at each site. Most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pleomorphic adenoma

Pleomorphic adenoma, the most common salivary gland tumor, is also known as benign mixed tumors (BMT's), because of its dual origin from epithelial and myoepithelial elements.It is the commonest of all salivary gland tumors constituting up to two-thirds of all salivary gland tumors.

choices.text: Do an urgent upper GI endoscopy
Put the patient in recovery position and secure airway
Insert a cannula and start IV fluids

questions.text: A 45 years old patient presented to you with ongoing massive hematemesis. The patient is alert and hemodynamically stable. What will be the first step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Put the patient in recovery position and secure airway
As a part of the BLS algorithm, we should start with the airway management in any patient who is collapsed/expected to collapse. Since the patient is hemodynamically stable, the airway is the most important component at risk in this patient and requires immediate attention. The patient should be put in a recovery position i.e. left lateral decubitus position to prevent the risk of aspiration.

choices.text: Within minutes to hours of transplantation

questions.text: Acute cellular rejection following solid organ transplantation occurs:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: A patient undergoes a prolonged and complicated pancreatic surgery for chronic pancreatitis. Most preferred route for supplementary nutrition in this patient would be:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Feeding jejunostomy

A feeding jejunostomy is the preferred procedure to provide supplementary nutrition in this patient as it provides protection to the pancreatic anastomosis and cause minimal stimulation of pancreatic secretion thereby giving rest to the pancreas. After pancreatic surgery, TPN should or only be used when there is intolerance to enteral nutrition or enteral nutrition is contraindicated. Pancreatic surgery does not usually interfere with the function of the gastrointestinal tract and enteral route remains the preferred mode for providing nutrition.

questions.text: 22 Gauge IV cannula color is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

blue

choices.text: Lateral and cephalad to the upper pole ureter
Lateral and caudal to the upper pole ureter
Medial and cephalad to the upper pole ureter
Medial and caudal to the upper pole ureter

questions.text: According to Weigert-Meyer’s rule of duplication of ureter, the lower pole ureter in urinary bladder is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lateral and cephalad to the upper pole ureter

Meyer-Weigert-Rule predicts the draining pattern of duplex ureters in bipolar renal duplications. The upper pole is normally seen as ectopic and therefore dysplastic due to obstruction, whereas the lower pole is related to vesicoureteral reflux.

questions.text: Hesselbach’s triangle is bounded by the following, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Transversus abdominis muscle

Indirect inguinal hernia comes out of abdominal cavity through deep inguinal ring, travel inguinal canal and becomes superficial through superficial inguinal ring. Direct inguinal hernia enters inguinal canal through medial half of weak posterior wall (Hesselbach’s triangle) and becomes superficial through superficial inguinal ring.

choices.text: Call patient one month after delivery

questions.text: A lady who is 9 weeks pregnant comes with a 2.5 cm mass in the upper outer quadrant of left breast. Ultrasound failed to show any abnormality. The ideal management will be to:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Finger guided core biopsy

Most breast lesions in pregnancy are benign but biopsy should be done to rule out malignancy. Core- needle biopsy with or without ultrasound guidance is a safe and reliable method for obtaining tissue.

questions.text: A 40-years-old female was diagnosed with CIN-3. What will be the management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Colposcopy + LEEP

The management CIN-3 in a 40 years old female include colposcopy + LEEP (Loop electrosurgical excision procedure).

questions.text: A 30-years-old primigravida presented at 10 weeks gestation with painless, bright red bleeding per vaginum. On examination, the uterus is 12 weeks size. Ultrasonography revealed the following picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hydatidiform mole

Sonographically, a complete mole appears as an echogenic uterine mass with numerous anechoic cystic spaces but without a fetus or amniotic sac. The appearance is often described as a “snowstorm”.

choices.text: Calcium: normal or decreased; Phosphate: increased; ALP: increased
Calcium: normal; Phosphate: normal; ALP: increased
Calcium: normal; Phosphate: normal; ALP: normal
Calcium: normal; Phosphate: decreased; ALP: increased

questions.text: A 65-year-old female with chronic backache revealed the following appearance on a lumbar radiograph. What is the most likely biochemical parameters associated?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Calcium: normal; Phosphate: normal; ALP: normal
Osteoporosis most likely shows Calcium: normal; Phosphate: normal; ALP: normal.

questions.text: An 18-year-old rugby player has pain in ring finger after missing tackle 1week ago. On Examination: tenderness in distal palm & inability to actively flex DIP joint. Diagnosis of Jersey finger is made. Most likely ruptured structure is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Flexor digitorum profundus
 
Rugger jersey finger — where there is injury to the flexor profundus tendon.

questions.text: Preferred treatment option for a 4 days old baby with bilirubin of 8 mg/ dL:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Continue breastfeeding and phototherapy

Preferred treatment option for a 4 days old baby with bilirubin of 8 mg/dL is to continue breastfeeding & phototherapy.

questions.text: What type of fracture is shown in the image?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Neer’s type III proximal humerus

In the given X-ray of proximal humerus fracture, there is three-part fracture, which fits it into Neer’s type III.

questions.text: A 38-year-old man was slapped over his right ear during fight. There is blood coming from his right external auditory canal. He describes pain as intense & has ringing in his ears.He is also noted to have decreased hearing on that ear. What is the most appropriate initial investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Otoscopy

From the history and the mechanism of injury, one can conclude that this patient has a perforated eardrum.Best investigation to do is still an otoscopy.

questions.text: A sexually active male presented with warts on his penis as shown during examination. Which of these strains of HPV is most commonly the cause of these lesions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

HPV 6 and 11

Genital warts are caused primarily by HPV-6 or HPV-11; their surface is either smooth or rough. Penile genital warts are usually 2-5 mm in diameter and often occur in groups.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man presents for an elective laparoscopic cholecystectomy. He is obese, has angina unpredictably and at rest, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). Which of the following would be his ASA classification?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

ASA IV

His angina at rest represents a systemic disease which is unstable, and which could be life threatening. In addition, he also has another comorbidity, COPD. His classification is ASA IV.

choices.text: ORS 50 ml per episode of loose stool
ORS 100 ml per episode of loose stool

questions.text: A 3-year-old child with weight of 12 kg is having loose motions. He is thirsty, drinks eagerly, tears are absent and skin pinch goes back slowly. What is the best treatment plan for this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

ORS 100 ml per episode of loose stool

For ongoing losses in children over 2 years, 100 ml per episode of loose stool should be given extra over the correction mentioned in first point.

questions.text: A hypertensive pregnant woman at 35 weeks comes with history of pain in abdomen, bleeding per vaginum and loss of fetal movements. On examination uterus is contracted with increased uterine tone. Fetal heart sounds are absent. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Abruptio placentae

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with a complaint of hearing loss in his right ear. On audiometric testing, a distinctive configuration is observed in the right ear, showing a notch or a dip at around 2,000 Hz. The hearing thresholds improve at higher frequencies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Otosclerosis Otosclerosis is a condition characterized by abnormal bone growth in the middle ear, which can lead to progressive hearing loss. However, the Carhart notch is not typically associated with otosclerosis. In otosclerosis, the hearing loss is often more gradual and affects a broader range of frequencies.This is the correct answer. The Carhart notch is commonly associated with noise-induced hearing loss. It is characterized by a distinct dip or notch in the audiogram at around 2,000 Hz. This notch occurs due to the damaging effects of prolonged or excessive noise exposure on the sensory cells in the cochlea, specifically affecting the frequencies within the speech range. The hearing thresholds usually improve at higher frequencies.

choices.text: Perform a finger sweep to clear the airway.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency department with acute choking. The patient is unable to speak, cough, or breathe and appears distressed. What is the most appropriate immediate action to be taken?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Perform the Heimlich maneuver
 
In a case of acute choking where the patient is unable to speak, cough, or breathe, performing the Heimlich maneuver is the most appropriate immediate action. The Heimlich maneuver involves applying pressure to the abdomen in a quick, upward motion to create a force that can dislodge an obstructing object from the airway. This technique can help clear the airway and restore breathing.

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with recurrent episodes of middle ear effusion, causing mild hearing loss and speech delay. Otoscopic examination reveals the presence of fluid behind both tympanic membranes (bilateral otitis media with effusion). What is the most appropriate initial treatment for this child’s glue ear?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Myringotomy with ventilation tube insertion

For a child with recurrent episodes of middle ear effusion causing mild hearing loss and speech delay (glue ear or otitis media with effusion), the most appropriate initial treatment is myringotomy with ventilation tube insertion.

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents to the clinic with a sore throat and difficulty swallowing. On examination, the child has enlarged tonsils with white exudates, fever, and tender cervical lymph nodes. The child is diagnosed with tonsillitis. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes)

Tonsillitis is an inflammation of the tonsils, which are the masses of lymphoid tissue located at the back of the throat. It can be caused by various pathogens, but the most common bacterial cause of tonsillitis, particularly in children, is Group A Streptococcus (Streptococcus pyogenes).

questions.text: Shown instrument is used for which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Myringotomy

Myringotomy is done by a sharp myringotome as shown in the image. Myringotome is a surgical knife used for paracentesis of the eardrum.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents to the emergency department with a harsh, high-pitched noise during inspiration. The infant appears agitated and is having difficulty breathing. On examination, there is audible inspiratory stridor, retractions, and nasal flaring. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the infant's symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Croup

Inspiratory stridor is a high-pitched noise heard during inspiration and is commonly associated with upper airway obstruction. It is important to identify the underlying cause of inspiratory stridor, as the management and potential complications can vary. In this case, the presentation of a 6-month-old infant with audible inspiratory stridor, retractions, nasal flaring, and agitation is consistent with croup. Croup, also known as laryngotracheobronchitis, is a viral infection that causes inflammation and narrowing of the upper airway, particularly the larynx and trachea. The characteristic "barking" cough and symptoms worsen at night, often leading to respiratory distress.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of a patient presenting with shown finding on tympanic membrane?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ear ache

Earache is not a feature of tubercular otitis media.Tuberculosis of the ear is usually secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis. It presents as a painless condition, with foul-smelling discharge from the ear. Multiple perforations in pars tensa of the tympanic membrane and pale granulations in the middle ear cleft are seen.

questions.text: A patient presented with glaucoma following cataract surgery, a moderate elevation of intraocular pressure that often follows replacement of crystalline lens. Which of the following is a choice for treatment and the correct mechanism for that drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Timolol—decreased synthesis of aqueous humor

Beta blockers such as timolol reduce intraocular pressure by reducing synthesis of aqueous by the ciliary epithelium

questions.text: A 30 year old smoker present to you with irritable cough and hoarseness with the history of atrophic rhinitis & pharyngitis, excessive crusts seen when you    perform    laryngoscopy. Laryngoscopic picture is shown in the given image. The diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Laryngitis sicca

Laryngitis sicca is characterized by atrophic changes in the respiratory mucosa. Crusts are the most important diagnostic features , generally the history with Tobacco smoke, dehydration,and pollution.

questions.text:
A 22-year-boy present with complaint of nasal discharge, nasal bleeding, headache and facial pain. He has recurrent sinusitis in previous years
. You examine him and see that his nasal septum is deviated . What is your next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Septoplasty

This is case of deviated nasal septum. We can do both septoplasty and submucous resection but septoplasty is preferred now a days because it is conservative procedure and have less complications.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman develops accelerated hypertension (blood pressure 216/106 mm Hg) but no clinical symptoms except frequent headaches. Which of the following findings are most likely on examination of the fundus examination?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cotton wool spots

Cotton wool spots, hemorrhage, and papilledema are common. Fibrinoid necrosis occurs on the arterioles of many organs.Earlier manifestations of arteriosclerosis include thickening of the vessel wall.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents with cicatricial entropion of upper and lower eyelid. On eversion of upper eyelid, linear conjunctival scars - Arlt's line are seen. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Trachoma

Arlt's line is a feature of trachoma. Signs of Trachoma Conjunctival signs :Congestion, conjunctival follicles (boiled sagograin like), Papillary hyperplasia, conjunctival scarring (Arlt line)

questions.text: A 23-year-old pregnant female presented with slowly progressive hearing loss, tinnitus and vertigo. On otoscope schwartz sign is positive. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Otosponigiosis

Schwartz’ sign (flamingo pink TM) is seen in Otosponigiosis also known as otosclerosis.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic female complaints of nocturnal otalgia & ear discharge. There is no significant deafness or vertigo & denies any ear trauma.On examination of external ear canal, granulation is seen. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Malignant otitis externa

Malignant external otitis (MEO) is an infection that affects the external auditory canal and temporal bone. The causative organism is usually Pseudomonas aeruginosa, and the disease commonly manifests in elderly patients with diabetes.

questions.text: An ENT specialist was trying to remove wax from the patient’s EAC and the patient started having cough. Which of these nerves is responsible for the cough:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Alderman’s nerve

Auricular vagus nerve is also known as Arnold's or Alderman's nerve (Nomura and Mizuno, 1984). It leaves the cervical VN at the level of the jugular ganglion where aVN have their bodies of the sensory ganglionic neurons, just outside the cranium.

questions.text: During resuscitation of a baby who did not cry at birth, even after the initial steps, the baby did not cry. Hence positive pressure ventilation with bag and mask was started. Which of the following is the most sensitive indicator that the baby is responding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Increase in heart rate

The primary measure of adequate initial ventilation is the prompt improvement in heart rate. Assisted ventilation should be delivered at a rate of 40 to 60 breaths per minute, to promptly achieve or maintain a heart rate >100 bpm (beats per min).

questions.text: A 7 year old child presented with complaints of hematuria with history of sore throat 2 weeks .On assessment, no fever and cola colored urine was noted. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

PSGN

Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) results from a bacterial infection that causes rapid deterioration of the kidney function due to an inflammatory response following streptococcal infection. PSGN most commonly presents in children 1 to 2 weeks after a streptococcal throat infection, or within 6 weeks following a streptococcal skin infection.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is associated with hypocalcemia, TOF, thymic hypoplasia and microdeletion in chromosome 22q11.2?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

DiGeorge syndrome

CATCH 22 syndrome is characterized by cardiac defects, abnormal facial features, thymic hypoplasia, cleft palate, and hypocalcemia. It results from a deletion within chromosome 22q11. This syndrome is not a simple disease. It includes DiGeorge syndrome, conotruncal anomaly face syndrome, and velocardiofacial syndrome.

questions.text: A 5 months child presented with difficulty in breathing , chest indrawing and wheeze of 1 day duration. Previous episodes of wheezing/ MDI usage is present. What is the next step in management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Oxygen inhalation + Salbutamol nebulisation

Oxygen inhalation + Salbutamol nebulisation is the most appropriate management to be done in the given condition.

choices.text: Get blood glucose levels, if low give IV glucose

questions.text: A 3 year child presents to Emergency Room with uprolling of eye balls and tonic posturing for last 2 minutes with peri-oral cyanosis, the initial step in management includes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Start oxygen

The priority step in treating seizures is always to ensure good oxygenation and ventilation since hypoxia is detrimental in a child with seizures. Oxygen by nasal cannula or mask, if needed, is administered, endotracheal intubation may be required. This should be followed by securing i.v line, checking sugars and giving anticonvulsant

questions.text: A 68-year-old diabetic male presents with persistent ear discharge with fever and headache. He complained of pain out of proportion. On examination, granulations and tenderness are observed on the floor of the external auditory canal along with facial nerve palsy. He is not responding to antibiotics. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Malignant otitis externa

" Presence of a painful lesion in the external ear with the evidence of granulation tissue and associated cranial nerve palsies (VII nerve) in a diabetic (or immunocompromised) patient suggest a diagnosis of malignant otitis externa.

choices.text: Topical antibiotics and decongestants for 4 weeks.

questions.text: A child presents with left ear hearing loss of three month duration. On examination, foul smelling purulent discharge is seen with perforation in pars flaccida. What is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Tympano-mastoid exploration

Foul-smelling discharge and perforation in the pars flaccida suggest CSOM of the unsafe type (Atticoantral type). Type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) has often associated with bone eroding processes such as cholesteatoma, granulations or osteitis. Risk of complications is high. Surgery is the mainstay of treatment. The primary aim is to remove the disease process by tympano- mastoid exploration and render the ear safe.

questions.text: A female who underwent laproscopic appendicectomy for acute appendicitis, on post -operative day 2 bumped her nose on to a table. She developed difficulty in breathing and examination showed a swelling in the anterior part of the nasal septum. Next line of management is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Incision and drainage

Nasal septal hematoma is a rare but potentially serious complication of nasal trauma. The trauma allows blood to pass into both mucoperichondrial planes. Because the septal cartilage has no blood supply of itself and receives all of its nutrients and oxygen from the perichondrium, untreated septal hematoma may lead to destruction of the septum resulting in a saddle nose deformity. Immediate drainage is necessary.

questions.text: ‘Griesinger sign’ is otalgia along with pain and edema over mastoid. It is typically seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Lateral sinus thrombosis

Lateral sinus thrombosis is a ominous complication of acute OM. It arises from extension of infection and inflammation in the mastoid, with eventual inflammation of the adjacent lateral or sigmoid sinus. Headache is the most common symptom, with papilledema, sixth-nerve palsy, and vertigo being less frequently present. Occlusion of the lateral sinus produces pain over the ear and mastoid and may cause edema over the mastoid (Griesinger sign). Involvement of cranial nerves V and VI produces ipsilateral facial pain and lateral rectus weakness (Gradenigo syndrome).

questions.text: The current treatment of choice for a large antrochoanal polyp in a 30-year- old man is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery)

Current treatment of choice of antrochoanal polypis endoscopic sinus surgery which has superceded other modes of polyp removal in all age groups. In this procedure all polyps are removed under endoscopic control especially from the key area of the osteomeatal complex. This procedure helps to preserve the normal function of the sinuses. FESS can be done under local anesthesia although general anesthesia is preferred. Caldwell-Luc operation is avoided these days.

questions.text: A 16-year-old male presents with a history of recurrent epistaxis (nosebleeds) and nasal obstruction on the right side. On examination, a highly vascular mass is visualized in the right nasal cavity. CT imaging reveals a soft tissue lesion centered in the pterygopalatine fossa, extending into the nasopharynx. The patient has no significant medical history. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma

Recurrent epistaxis in a young adolescent male with unilateral nasal mass is due to Juvenile nasopharyngeal angiofibroma.

choices.text: Capsule of tonsil and superior constrictor muscle

questions.text: Danger space is located between:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Alar fascia and prevertebral fascia

Danger/alar space: Lies between alar fascia anteriorly and prevertebral fascia posteriorly. That is it lies just posterior to the retropharyngeal space. Extends from skull base to diaphragm. An infection from this space can spread to the mediastinum.

questions.text: Most common cause for bilateral Recurrent laryngeal Nerve paralysis:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Surgical trauma

Surgical trauma is the most common cause for bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis. The incidence of permanent RLN paralysis is approximately 1% to 1.5% for total thyroidectomy and less for near-total procedures

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of double vision. On examination, his left eye shows a significant limitation of abduction. All other extraocular movements are intact. Which of the following muscles is most likely affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Lateral rectus

The lateral rectus muscle is responsible for abduction, which is the movement of the eye away from the midline. In this case, the patient presents with a limitation of abduction in the left eye. This indicates dysfunction of the lateral rectus muscle.

questions.text: A 62-year-old patient presents to the ophthalmology clinic with complaints of gradually progressive loss of vision in both eyes over the past 6 months. Intraocular pressure (IOP) measurements are found to be elevated in both eyes. On examination, the patient has cupping of the optic discs, with a vertical cup-to-disc ratio of 0.8. Visual field testing reveals peripheral visual field loss in both eyes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Primary open-angle glaucoma
 
The clinical presentation of gradually progressive loss of vision, elevated IOP, cupping of the optic discs (as evidenced by a high vertical cup-to-disc ratio), and peripheral visual field loss is highly suggestive of glaucoma. Among the given options, the most likely diagnosis in this case is Primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG), which is the most common form of glaucoma.

questions.text: The most common method of anterior capsulotomy in phaco- emulsification:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Capsulorhexis

The most commonly used technique for anterior capsulotomy during phacoemulsification is continuous curvilinear capsulorhexis (CCC). Cataract surgery is the most commonly performed ophthalmic procedure worldwide with major anatomical and optical goal being, a well-centered posterior chamber intraocular lens (IOL). Anterior capsulotomy has evolved from an era of can- opener capsulotomy to circular capsulorhexis (CCC) and more recently to precision pulse anterior capsulotomy. A smooth-edged capsulotomy renders the capsular bag opening its strength, for subsequent steps of phacoemulsification and is considered ideal if it is round, continuous, wellcentered, and overlaps the IOL around its circumference.

questions.text: Thinnest portion of sclera:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Posterior to rectus muscle insertion

Thinnest portion of sclera: Posterior to insertions of rectus muscle. Thickest portion of sclera: Posterior pole.

questions.text: Female presents with galactorrhoea and amenorrhea and diagnosed with Pituitary adenoma and now complains of loss of vision which will be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Bitemporal hemianopia

The characteristic visual field defect caused by pituitary adenomas with suprasellar extension is bitemporal hemianopsia.

questions.text: Microaneurysms	are	hallmark lesions in which disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Diabetic retinopathy

Microaneurysms are usually the earliest visible manifestation of diabetic retinopathy. They appear as tiny red dots scattered in the retina posteriorly. They may be surrounded by a ring of yellow lipid, or hard, exudates.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child presents to the emergency department with complaints of fever, headache, and swelling around the left eye. On examination, there is proptosis, limitation of extraocular movements, and edema of the eyelids. The child is unable to open the left eye fully. There is also tenderness on palpation of the affected area. Visual acuity is decreased in the left eye. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Orbital cellulitis

The clinical presentation of proptosis, limitation of extraocular movements, eyelid edema, and decreased visual acuity in a child with fever and headache is highly suggestive of orbital cellulitis. Orbital cellulitis is an infection that involves the soft tissues located within the orbit, and it is commonly seen in children. It usually arises as a complication of sinusitis, with the infection spreading from the paranasal sinuses to the orbit.

questions.text: “Pie in the sky” field defect is seen in lesion of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Temporal lobe

A lesion in Meyer's loop causes a contralateral homonymous superior quadrantanopia, sometimes
termed a “pie-in-the-sky” defect.

questions.text: A clinical condition seen in a 24 year old male is characterised by a facial palsy and is often associated with facial pain and the appearance of vesicles on the canal and pinna. Vertigo and sensor neural hearing loss (VIIIth nerve) accompanying it is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ramsay Hunt syndrome

Ramsay Hunt cerebellar syndrome, is a rare form of cerebellar degeneration which involves myoclonic epilepsy, progressive ataxia, tremor, and a dementing process. Ramsay Hunt syndrome type 2- A triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, ear pain, and vesicles on the face, on the ear, or in the ear is the typical presentation. Ramsay Hunt syndrome type 3 is a less commonly referenced condition, an occupationally induced neuropathy of the deep palmar branch of the ulnar nerve. It is also called Hunt's disease or artisan’s palsy.

questions.text: Nasolacrimal duct opens in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Inferior meatus of nose
 
The duct descends downward, backward, and the nasolacrimal duct is about 0.5 in. (1.3 cm) laterally in a bony canal and opens into the inferior meatus of the nose. The opening is guarded by a fold of mucous membrane known as the lacrimal fold.

questions.text: A 64-year hypertensive obese female was undergoing surgery for fracture femur under general anaesthesia. Intraoperatively her end tidal CO2 volume decreased to 20 from 40 mmHg followed by hypotension and oxygen saturation of 85%. What could be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Fat embolism

Fat embolism is usually seen after long bone fracture. It becomes more fulminant after reaming of long bones especially femur. The clinical presentation is dyspnea, restlessness, tachycardia, hypotension, mental clouding and persistently falling oxygen saturation, petechial hemorrhages over chest and axilla. End tidal carbon dioxide falls.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with a three-month history of intermittent right hip pain and a limp. On physical examination, there is limited range of motion in the right hip, especially with internal rotation. Radiographs of the hip reveal a flattened femoral head with sclerosis and fragmentation. Based on these findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease

The most likely diagnosis in this case is Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease. Legg-Calvé-Perthes disease, also known as Perthes disease, is a condition that affects the blood supply to the femoral head, leading to avascular necrosis and subsequent deformity. It primarily affects children between the ages of 4 and 10, with boys being more commonly affected than girls. The typical presentation includes hip pain, limp, and limited range of motion, especially with internal rotation. Radiographic findings often show a flattened femoral head with sclerosis and fragmentation.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with a painful left forearm after falling from his bicycle. On examination, there is obvious deformity of the left elbow with swelling and tenderness. Radiographs reveal a proximal ulnar fracture with anterior dislocation of the radial head. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Monteggia fracture

Monteggia fracture is a rare but significant injury involving a fracture of the proximal third of the ulna associated with dislocation of the radial head. It is commonly seen in children but can also occur in adults. The mechanism of injury is usually a fall on an outstretched hand or a direct blow to the forearm

questions.text: A 7-year-old child presents to the emergency department with a swollen and painful right knee. The child is unable to bear weight on the affected leg and has a fever. On physical examination, there is warmth, tenderness, and limited range of motion in the right knee. The child has no history of recent trauma. What is the most likely diagnosis for the child’s current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Septic arthritis

7-year-old child presents with a swollen and painful right knee, along with the inability to bear weight on the affected leg and fever. On physical examination, there is warmth, tenderness, and limited range of motion in the right knee. Notably, there is no history of recent trauma.Based on these findings, the most likely diagnosis for the child’s current condition is septic arthritis, also known as acute suppurative arthritis. Septic arthritis is a severe bacterial infection of a joint, which can affect people of all ages, including children.

choices.text: Closed reduction and immobilization in a knee brace
Open reduction and internal fixation with tension band wiring
Non-operative management with a knee immobilizer and non-weight bearing
Arthroscopic debridement and loose body removal

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents to the emergency department with severe pain and swelling in his right knee after a fall. On examination, there is tenderness, swelling, and a palpable gap over the patella. Radiographs reveal a transverse fracture of the patella with displacement. What is the most appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Open reduction and internal fixation with tension band wiring

Patella fractures can occur due to direct trauma or indirect forces, such as a fall onto a flexed knee. When a patella fracture is displaced, surgical intervention is usually required to achieve adequate reduction and stability. Tension band wiring is a commonly used technique for the fixation of transverse patella fractures.In this case, the clinical presentation of severe pain, swelling, and a palpable gap over the patella, along with the radiographic findings of a transverse fracture with displacement, indicate the need for surgical management.

questions.text: An elderly male with symptoms of sinusitis and an incidental finding in the skull. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Paget’s disease

This is a rarefied area involving the frontal and parietal bones, and it is an early stage of Paget’s disease
in which calvarial thickening and foci or radiopacity are not present within the radiolucent area.

questions.text: A labourer’s second child is brought to the OPD with a swollen belly and dull face. He has been fed rice water (rice milk) in his diet mostly. On investigations, the child is found to have low serum protein and low albumin. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Kwashiorkor

A poor diet history (rice water) and a swollen belly are suggestive of Kwashiorkor. Kwashiorkor is a form of severe acute malnutrition (SAM) characterized by oedema and apathy.

questions.text: A 3-year-old male has the following buccal mucosa finding. After three days, he presents to your OPD with a rash. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Measles
 
The given image shows Koplik spots which are small, bluish-white ulcerations on the buccal mucosa opposite the lower molar tooth. The clinical scenario and Koplik spots are suggestive of measles.

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl was brought by her mother with complaints of enlarged clitoris. Karyotype revealed 46XX. What is the likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

21 hydroxylase deficiency

The likely cause in the given clinical scenario is congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), in which 21- hydroxylase deficiency causes ambiguous genitalia in females due to increased serum androgens.

questions.text: A newborn is brought with evisceration of bowel loops from a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus. The most probable diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Gastrochisis

The most probable diagnosis for the evisceration of bowel loops, coming out of a defect in the abdominal wall to the right of the umbilicus is gastroschisis. It occurs when there is a failure in the closure of the body wall in the abdominal region.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the clinic by his parents due to episodes of cyanosis that occur during crying and feeding. On examination, the infant appears well and has a grade 3/6 systolic murmur along the left sternal border. The liver edge is palpable 3 cm below the right costal margin. Radiological finding is as shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Tetralogy of Fallot

The most likely diagnosis in this case is D) Tetralogy of Fallot. Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF) is a congenital heart defect that consists of four anatomical abnormalities: pulmonary stenosis, right ventricular hypertrophy, overriding aorta, and ventricular septal defect (VSD). In this case, the infant presents with episodes of cyanosis that occur during crying and feeding. This is consistent with the characteristic "tet spell" seen in TOF, where the cyanosis worsens during episodes of increased cardiac output and decreased systemic vascular resistance. The grade 3/6 systolic murmur along the left sternal border is due to the presence of pulmonary stenosis, which is a hallmark feature of TOF. Additionally, the palpable liver edge 3 cm below the right costal margin suggests right ventricular hypertrophy causing hepatomegaly.

questions.text: Contraceptive option available to a 28-year-old breastfeeding mother with 6 week old baby, wishing to avoid next pregnancy are the following except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

OCP

OCP in Lactating mother can Adversely affect the quantity and constituents of breast milk May result premature cessation of lactation.

choices.text: Mid year population between 15 to 49 years of age in the same year
Mid year women population between 15 to 49 years of age in the same year
Mid year married women between 15 to 49 years of age in the same year of age
Live births in the same year

questions.text: General fertility rate is a better measure of fertility in defining GFR , which of the following is taken as the denominator?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mid year women population between 15 to 49 years of age in the same year

Explanation : GFR is the no of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group ( 15 to 44 or 49 years) in a given year. It is better measure of fertility than crude birth rate , but it’s limitation is that not all women are exposed to risk of child birth .

questions.text: Live attenuated vaccines are:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Measles, Mumps, BCG, Varicella

There are both live attenuated vaccines and killed vaccines against plague.

questions.text: The physician recommends administering vaccines that are not sensitive to heat due to the environmental conditions. Which of the following is not heat sensitive vaccine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Inactivated polio vaccine (IPV)
IPV is not sensitive to heat and can be stored and transported at higher temperatures without affecting its efficacy. It is a suitable choice for this patient and the environmental conditions described.
Vaccines sensitive to Heat are: BCG, OPV, Measles, DPT, DT, TT, Hep B, JE

questions.text: In 1980, ICIDH (International Classification of Impairment, Disability and Handicap) was published by the WHO as a manual of classification relating to the consequences of disease. In an accident, a person lost his leg. According to ICIDH this is an example for:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Impairment

Impairment is an absence of or significant difference in a person's body structure or function or mental functioning.

choices.text: Requires complete understanding of all factors associated with causation of disease
Helps to suggest ways to interrupt the risk of transmission

questions.text: “Web of causation of disease”, which statement is most appropriate?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Helps to suggest ways to interrupt the risk of transmission

It was formulated to explain causation of non-communicable diseases. Multiple factors interact with each other similar to web of a spider and modify the effect of each other. Each factor has its own relative importance. To prevent a disease, we need to identify and act on the “weakest links” in the inter-lacing webs.

questions.text: Continuous scrutiny of the factors that determine the occurrence and distribution of disease and others conditions of ill-health is known as surveillance. The National Health Program of India collects data for morbidity and mortality mainly by which type of surveillance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Passive surveillance

Routine health information system is a passive system in which regular reports about diseases and programs are compiled by public health staff members, hospitals, and clinics.

questions.text: An action which halts the progress of a disease at its incipient stage and prevents complications is called:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Secondary prevention

Secondary prevention is action taken to halt the progress of disease in early pathogenesis phase and prevent complications.

questions.text: Which one of the following methods is used for the estimation of chlorine demand of water?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Horrock’s apparatus

Horrock’s apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water and to find out the dose of
bleaching powder required for disinfection of water.

questions.text: Setting up of condom vending machines at public places in high HIV prevalence areas is an example of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Social Marketing

Social marketing approach in family planning programs makes contraceptive Accessible and Affordable It uses commercial marketing techniques to achieve specific behavioral goals. Social marketers combine product, price, place (distribution), and promotion— “4Ps” or the “marketing mix”—to maximize use of specific health products among targeted population groups. It seeks to improve access by tapping into networks of private providers and non-governmental sector outlets, such as pharmacies, shops, community-based distributors, private health care providers/outlets, kiosks, and community health workers.

questions.text: The national health plan recommended one PHC for how many people in hilly and tribal areas:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

20000

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presents to the ED with concerns of having a heart ailment. He says that he has been concerned about having a heart attack for the past 12 months. He constantly searches the Internet to read about symptoms associated with heart disease and survival rates of people having heart disease. He reports that his worry is causing him a great deal of stress and concern. Medical history is unremarkable. Family history is significant for a myocardial infarction in his father just over a year ago, who is currently living without significant morbidity. Vital signs, physical examination and a 12-lead electrocardiogram (ECG) are all normal. Which of the following diagnoses fits best with the patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypochondriacal disorder

This patient has hypochondriacal disorder, now more commonly called illness anxiety disorder. There is a strong belief in the presence of an underlying serious disease such as cancer. The patient refuses to accept any reassurance despite normal examination and investigations.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman is brought to Emergency Department by her mother. Her mother is concerned that her daughter appears unwell. She tells the Physician that since coming home for the summer holidays, her daughter has not been herself. She barely eats and has lost a dramatic amount of weight. Questioning reveals that the patient has no history of fevers or night sweats. 2 Clinical examination reveals a young woman with a body mass index (BMI) of 16 kg/ m , who appears malnourished. She claims to have little to no appetite, and her mother confirms she has overheard her daughter vomiting regularly after each meal. Physical examination reveals cachexia, a fine lanugo on the patient's face, a patchy, irregular alopecia across the back of her head and a firm but compressible mass in the left upper quadrant. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for her symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Trichobezoar

The clinical examination demonstrates a compressible mass within the abdomen, significant malnutrition and patches of alopecia. This is the classic clinical appearance of trichobezoar. It is seen in people who consume their hair, which is a recognised feature of some anxiety states. The lanugo on this patient's face is not a definitive sign of trichotillomania, but results from the concomitant cachexia. The patient's body has regrown the soft hair on newborns in an attempt to thermally regulate the body. It may be seen in patients with anorexia and bulimia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is referred with reduced energy levels, difficulty sleeping and low mood, symptoms he has been experiencing for several months. His wife divorced him last year on grounds of unreasonable behaviour, when he became withdrawn and refused to do anything around the house after losing his job. On further questioning, he also admits to hearing voices telling him that he is useless. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Depression

This patient suffers key symptoms of depression such as persistent low energy levels, and low mood (for greater than at least two weeks) as described by the ICD-10. He also suffers associated symptoms of sleep disturbance. He has psychotic elements to his illness as evidenced by auditory hallucinations in the second person, which can occur in affective disorders. The constellation of these symptoms makes depression the most likely answer.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man attends the Outpatient Clinic. He has no prior medical history. He is obsessed with washing his hands and spends up to one hour doing this each morning and evening. He says he feels that he is dirty. He is also concerned about security and checks the doors at home a number of times before leaving the house. On examination, he is in a low mood. He is slowed up in speech, but coherent. Which of the following is the first-line treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Cognitive behavioural therapy

Given this clinical picture of repetitive behaviour that is intrusive and consumes a significant amount of time during the day, obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD) appears to be the most likely diagnosis. Associated depression is quite possible and is related to an inability to overcome the repetitive cycles of behaviour. The incidence of OCD may be as high as 1–2% of the adult population and the condition occurs with roughly equal sex incidence. Cognitive behavioural therapy should be offered as the first line for OCD.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents to the clinic with a chief complaint of believing that his wife has been replaced by an imposter. He claims that although she looks identical, she behaves differently and does not have the same emotional connection as his real wife. This delusional belief is limited to his wife and does not extend to other people. The patient has a history of a recent head injury. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Capgras syndrome

Capgras syndrome is a psychiatric disorder characterized by the delusional belief that a person, usually a close family member or friend, has been replaced by an identical imposter. The patient typically recognizes the person's physical appearance but believes that their behavior, gestures, or emotional connection are different or absent. The delusional belief is limited to the specific person and does not extend to other individuals.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency department following an uneventful appendectomy. In the postoperative period, the patient developed a rapid rise in body temperature, generalized muscle rigidity, tachycardia, and metabolic acidosis. His urine output is significantly decreased with shown capnography. The patient has a family history of adverse reactions to anesthesia. Which of the following is the drug of choice for management of the condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Dantrolene

Described case with capnographic finding suggests Malignant hyperthermia. Dantrolene sodium uncouples the heat-generating mechanism in muscle and is the drug of choice in treating malignant hyperthermia and neuroleptic malignant syndrome, which cause excessive muscular heat production.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves is popularly used in clinical anaesthesia to monitor neuromuscular blockade?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Ulnar Nerve

Ulnar nerve stimulation at wrist is popularly used to assess the adequacy of neuromuscular blockade. Neuromuscular blockade is measured using a peripheral nerve stimulator.

questions.text: Identify the Mallampatti class of this patient.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Class III

The image shows Mallampatti class Il airway.
The modified Mallampatti classification is used in the assessment of airway. It is a predictor of the difficulty of intubation or difficult airway. The assessment is performed with the patient sitting up straight, mouth open and tongue maximally protruded, without saying "ahh."
Modified Mallampati classification:
•	Class 0: Ability to see any part of the epiglottis.
•	Class I: Soft palate, fauces, uvula visible.
•	Class II: Soft palate and fauces seen, tip of uvula not visible.

questions.text: What is the most effective circuit for anaesthesia under spontaneous breathing?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Mapleson A

The most effective circuit for anesthesia under spontaneous breathing is Mapleson A or Magill's circuit. When the Mapleson A circuit is used for spontaneous ventilation, the fresh gas flow rate of the circuit is closest to the physiological minute ventilation of the patient. Hence it is preferred over other circuits.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was intubated for surgery by a final-year resident. Which of the following is the best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

End-tidal CO2 concentration

The best method to confirm the position of the endotracheal tube is the end-tidal CO2 concentration assessed by capnography. Capnography is a non-invasive method of measurement and graphical display of partial pressure of carbon dioxide (CO₂) in exhaled breath or the end- tidal CO₂ Capnograph is the device used for measurement and capnogram is the CO2 waveform that is displayed. It is the most reliable indicator of endotracheal tube placement.

questions.text: Which among the following is an example of epimers?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

D-glucose and D- mannose

Explanation: D-GIucose and D-mannose are examples of epimers.
Isomers that differ in configuration around only one specific carbon atom (with the exception of the carbonyl carbon) are defined as epimers of each other.
Examples for epimers of glucose:
•	Mannose (epimerized at carbon 2)
•	Galactose (epimerized at carbon 4)

questions.text: A 9-year old child presents chronic fatigue, growth retardation and epistaxis. On further evaluation, hepatosplenomegaly,	thrombo- cytopenia and anemia was found. X-ray of the femur showed Erlenmeyer flask deformity. Bone marrow biopsy showed cells with wrinkled tissue paper appearance. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Gaucher's disease
 
Explanation: The above clinical features and bone marrow biopsy showing cells with wrinkled tissue paper appearance suggest Gaucher's disease.
Gaucher's disease is a genetic disorder in which glucocerebroside accumulates in cells and certain organs due to the deficiency of the enzyme glucocerebrosidase (Pglucosidase).
It is the most common lysosomal storage disorder.

questions.text: A 23-year old woman is on chronic therapy with the anti-TB drug Isoniazid. Which of the following vitamin deficiencies can be seen in this individual?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Pyridoxine

Explanation: Isoniazid, a drug used to treat tuberculosis, can induce a vitamin B6 deficiency. Isoniazid forms an inactive derivative with Pyridoxal phosphate. In those on chronic isoniazid treatment, additional vitamin B6 supplements are given.

questions.text: A 41-year-old man, who is consuming jowar for a long duration, now presents with rashes in the sun- exposed area like dorsum of the hand, around the neck, as shown in the image below. Which is the vitamin deficient in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Vitamin B3

Explanation:	The image depicts above shows the characteristic Casal’s necklace pattern, seen in
pellagra caused due to deficiency of vitamin B3 / Niacin.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an intermediate of the TCA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Acetyl CoA

Explanation: Acetyl COA is not an intermediate formed in TCA, but rather a starting material for TCA.

questions.text: The glycosaminoglycan present in the cornea is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Keratan sulfate

Explanation: Keratan sulfate I is present in the cornea.
Keratan sulfate is made of repeating units of N-acetyl glucosamine and galactose. 2 types of keratan sulfate are seen:
Keratan sulfate I is present in the cornea. Keratan sulfate II is mainly present in the cartilage. Keratan sulfate is present between the collagen fibrils in the cornea and plays a major role in corneal transparency.

questions.text: Pellagra-like symptoms can be due to all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Wernicke's encephalopathy

Explanation: Pellagra-like symptoms are not seen in Wernicke’s encephalopathy.
Pellagra can be due to dietary niacin deficiency or deficient conversion of tryptophan to niacin. Hence pellagra-like symptoms are seen in:
