Hartnup disease: It is an autosomal recessive disease caused by mutations in the SLC6A 19 gene, defective membrane transport of tryptophan across PCT (kidney) and enterocytes (intestine) leading to malabsorption of tryptophan. This causes a deficiency of tryptophan.
Carcinoid syndrome: due to excess conversion of tryptophan to serotonin, resulting in a decreased level of tryptophan for niacin synthesis

choices.text: Centromere is an adenine-thymine (A-T)- rich region containing repeated DNA sequences
Telomeres consist of short TTAGGG-rich repeats
Each sister chromatid contains one dsDNA molecule

questions.text: Which of the following is true about DNA organization in chromo- somes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Centromere is an adenine-thymine (A-T)-rich region containing repeated DNA sequences Explanation: The centromere is an adenine-thymine (A-T)-rich region containing repeated DNA sequence.
The ends of each chromosome contain structures called telomeres, which have a variable number of
repeats of the sequence 5’ -TTAGGG-3’
At metaphase, mammalian chromosomes possess a two-fold symmetry, with the identical duplicated sister chromatids connected at a centromere, in which each sister chromatid contains one dsDNA molecule.

questions.text: The parent purine nucleotide made from de novo purine synthesis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

IMP
Explanation: Inosine monophosphate (IMP) is the parent purine nucleotide made from de novo purine synthesis.
Ribose 5-phosphate is converted to inosine monophosphate (IMP) by series of reactions. Following the synthesis of IMP, separate branches lead to AMP and GMP synthesis.

questions.text: What is the end product of breakdown of purine nucleotides?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

URic acid

Explanation: Uric acid is the end product of purine catabolism.
Inside the intestinal mucosal cells, purine nucleotides are sequentially degraded by specific enzymes to nucleosides and free bases, with uric acid as the end product of this pathway.
The free bases are sent out from the liver and salvaged by peripheral tissues.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes catalyze the rate-limiting step of glycogenolysis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Glycogen phosphorylase

Explanation: The rate-limiting step in glycogenolysis is catalyzed by the enzyme, glycogen phosphorylase

questions.text: A 6-year-old child presents with hyperuricemia	and	delayed developmental milestones. He also has the habit of biting his lips, fingers, and feet because of which he is always strapped to the bed. Urine examined showed orange sands. Which is the most probable enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase

The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of Lesch-Nyhan syndrome. It is caused due to the complete deficiency of Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT).
Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is an X-Iinked recessive disorder. This deficiency results in an inability to salvage hypoxanthine or guanine, from which excessive amounts of uric acid is produced and excreted in urine as orange sands.

questions.text:
A 46-year-old female, who is known to have a case of DVT is on warfarin therapy from a long-duration. Which of the following clotting factor 
level may not be affected by warfarin therapy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Factor 8

Explanation: Warfarin, which is an oral anticoagulant drug inhibits Gamma carboxylation of clotting factors II, VII, X, but not factor Vlll.
Warfarin will inhibit Vitamin K epoxide reductase, an enzyme required for the reduction of vitamin K.

questions.text: In oxidative phosphorylation, the ATP production and respiratory chain are linked by:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Chemiosmotic methods

Explanation: The chemiosmotic theory states that the two processes (respiratory chain and synthesis of ATP) are coupled by a proton gradient across the inner mitochondrial membrane.
The proton motive force caused by the electrochemical potential difference drives the mechanism of ATP synthesis.

questions.text: A 1 year old male infant presents to the ER with vomiting, lethargy, and severe jaundice when he was fed with fruit juice. Which of the following enzymes is defective?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Aldolase B

Explanation: The appearance of above clinical features on the initiation of fruit juice suggests a disorder of fructose metabolism. Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) is due to deficiency of the enzyme Aldolase B

questions.text: Which of the following retinoids has major role to play in vision?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Retinal

Explanation: Retinal (retinaldehyde) has a major role to play in vision.
In the retina, retinaldehyde functions as the prosthetic group of the light-sensitive opsin proteins, which form rhodopsin (in rods) and iodopsin (in cones). Rhodopsin contains Il-cis retinal bound to opsin.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is an example of point mutation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sickle cell disease

Explanation: The classic example is of point mutation sicklecell disease.
This is caused by mutation of a single base out of the 3 x 109 in the genome, a T-to-A DNA substitution, which in turn results in an A-to-U change in the mRNA corresponding to the sixth codon of the ß- globin gene.

questions.text: A patient presents with abdominal pain and distension. An X ray was taken which showed dilated bowel loops as given in the image below. Identify the segment involved.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Jejunum
 
The given clinical scenario and X-ray suggest intestinal Obstruction where the involved segment is the jejunum. The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae connivente (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) which is characteristic of jejunal involvement. The gas bubbles trapped between the valvulae connivente give a string of beads appearance.

questions.text: A baby is brought to the clinic as he appears to turn blue every time he cries. Chest x-ray reveals the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ebstein anomaly

The given X-ray shows an enlarged, box-shaped cardiac silhouette that is typically seen in Ebstein's anomaly.

questions.text: A neonate is being evaluated for urinary abnormalities. Ultra-sono- graphy reveals the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Posterior urethral valve

The given image show dilated proximal urethra and associated thick-walled distended bladder on ultrasound that resembles a keyhole. This keyhole sign is seen in the presence of posterior urethral valves.

questions.text: Identify the marked vessel shown in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Anterior cerebral artery

The given image shows the MR angiography of cerebral circulation, The structure marked is the anterior cerebral artery which is a branch Of the internal carotid artery.

questions.text: A gallium-67 scan was performed on a patient and showed the following. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sarcoidosis

This is due to symmetrical uptake Of gallium-67 into the nasopharynx, lacrimal glands, parotid glands due to bilateral involvement Of the glands in sarcoidosis. Given image is shows Panda sign.
